R Functions and Plotly

The following is an assignment I completed which includes sorting a data set to find the desired data, creating functions which can then be reused later, and finally creating figures to represent the data.

Morelle Tinsley https://morellet54.netlify.app (Spacely Sprockets)https://example.com/spacelysprokets
2021-05-03

Filtering Data Using Functions

The Following uses a data set of flights from New York City.

  1. First, I created a function to filter the data to only show flights in the dataset which originate from JFK
# A tibble: 6 x 19
   year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time
  <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>
1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830
2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850
3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923
4  2013     1     1      544            545        -1     1004
5  2013     1     1      554            600        -6      812
6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740
#  with 12 more variables: sched_arr_time <int>, arr_delay <dbl>,
#   carrier <chr>, flight <int>, tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>,
#   dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>, hour <dbl>,
#   minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>
  1. The next function will do two things: first, it will filter the data frame to only include records from a single originating airport, and then aggregate the results by airline to show how many flights each airline has from that airport.
# A tibble: 6 x 19
   year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time
  <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>
1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830
2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850
3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923
4  2013     1     1      544            545        -1     1004
5  2013     1     1      554            600        -6      812
6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740
#  with 12 more variables: sched_arr_time <int>, arr_delay <dbl>,
#   carrier <chr>, flight <int>, tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>,
#   dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>, hour <dbl>,
#   minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>
# A tibble: 10 x 2
   carrier     n
   <chr>   <int>
 1 9E      14651
 2 AA      13783
 3 B6      42076
 4 DL      20701
 5 EV       1408
 6 HA        342
 7 MQ       7193
 8 UA       4534
 9 US       2995
10 VX       3596
  1. Below, I have created a function which: shows only flights which originate from JFK, whose flight times are greater than 400 minutes, and then aggregates the results to show how many flights with these attributes each airline has.
# A tibble: 6 x 19
   year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time
  <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>
1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830
2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850
3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923
4  2013     1     1      544            545        -1     1004
5  2013     1     1      554            600        -6      812
6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740
#  with 12 more variables: sched_arr_time <int>, arr_delay <dbl>,
#   carrier <chr>, flight <int>, tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>,
#   dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>, hour <dbl>,
#   minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>
# A tibble: 6 x 2
  carrier     n
  <chr>   <int>
1 AA          6
2 B6          2
3 DL          7
4 HA        342
5 UA          4
6 VX          4

Plotly Charts

Now, I will use a package in RStudio called Plotly to create charts from the filtered data.

  1. First, I will create a bar chart of how many flights each airline has that originate from JFK, and are greater than 400 minutes in length.
# A tibble: 6 x 19
   year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time
  <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>
1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830
2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850
3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923
4  2013     1     1      544            545        -1     1004
5  2013     1     1      554            600        -6      812
6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740
#  with 12 more variables: sched_arr_time <int>, arr_delay <dbl>,
#   carrier <chr>, flight <int>, tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>,
#   dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>, hour <dbl>,
#   minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>
# A tibble: 6 x 2
  carrier     n
  <chr>   <int>
1 AA          6
2 B6          2
3 DL          7
4 HA        342
5 UA          4
6 VX          4
  1. Now, I will use a function to filter the data set to show how many flights each airline has with the destination of Daniel K. Inouye International Airport (HNL) in Honolulu.
# A tibble: 6 x 19
   year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time
  <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>
1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830
2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850
3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923
4  2013     1     1      544            545        -1     1004
5  2013     1     1      554            600        -6      812
6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740
#  with 12 more variables: sched_arr_time <int>, arr_delay <dbl>,
#   carrier <chr>, flight <int>, tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>,
#   dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>, hour <dbl>,
#   minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>
# A tibble: 2 x 2
  carrier     n
  <chr>   <int>
1 HA        342
2 UA        365
  1. The final type of plotly chart I will show here is a scatter plot. First, I will filter the data set to show only flights with a destination of HNL, Honolulu. Then, I will input the departure and arrival delays into the x and y axes, respectively, to show the relationship between departure delays and arrival delays.
# A tibble: 6 x 19
   year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time
  <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>
1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830
2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850
3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923
4  2013     1     1      544            545        -1     1004
5  2013     1     1      554            600        -6      812
6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740
#  with 12 more variables: sched_arr_time <int>, arr_delay <dbl>,
#   carrier <chr>, flight <int>, tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>,
#   dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>, hour <dbl>,
#   minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>
